arm_group.description: ICU patients with Acute kidney injury

brief_summary.textblock:
B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) is rapidly released by the ventricles of the heart in
      response to myocardial stretch. This cardiac neurohormone is mostly elevated in patients
      with fluid overload or myocardium dysfunction. BNP is a very useful and important marker. It
      can predict mortality and cardiac events in patients in the ICU setting. In stable
      hemodialysis patients with normal LV function on echocardiography, high BNP levels are
      likely the result of blood volume expansion and require reduction in postdialysis dry
      weight.

      In the past, there were many methods to evaluate fluid status. Some are not reliable such as
      central venous pressure or physical examination. Some are invasive and expensive such as
      Swan Ganz、PiCCO catheter or bioimpedance device. Nevertheless, About the relationship
      between BNP and fluid status, a study found a significant relation between
      bioimpedance-derived body composition (BC) (fluid distribution) parameters and BNP
      concentrations. This relationship was independent of the cardiac history of the patient and
      suggests that the natriuretic peptide levels are to some degree modifiable by changing a
      patient's fluid distribution.

      In this study, the investigators want to observe that if the level of BNP can predict the
      occurrence of acute kidney injury and the need of renal replacement therapy. Besides, the
      investigators also want to see if BNP can be a useful and convenient marker to guide
      adjustment of optimal fluid status and then to improve outcome.

clinical_study.brief_title: Exploring the Relationship Among BNP, Fluid Status and Acute Kidney Injury in Critically Ill Patients

detailed_description.textblock:
B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) is rapidly released by the ventricles of the heart in
      response to myocardial stretch. This cardiac neurohormone is mostly elevated in patients
      with fluid overload or myocardium dysfunction. BNP is a very useful and important marker. It
      can predict mortality and cardiac events in patients in the ICU setting. In stable
      hemodialysis patients with normal LV function on echocardiography, high BNP levels are
      likely the result of blood volume expansion and require reduction in postdialysis dry
      weight.

      On the other hand, ample recent data have highlighted the role of ﬂuid accumulation on
      mortality and non-recovery of kidney function in critically ill patients with acute kidney
      injury (AKI). In the past, there were many methods to evaluate fluid status. Some are not
      reliable such as central venous pressure or physical examination. Some are invasive and
      expensive such as Swan Ganz、PiCCO catheter or bioimpedance device. Nevertheless, About the
      relationship between BNP and fluid status, a study found a significant relation between
      bioimpedance-derived body composition (BC) (fluid distribution) parameters and BNP
      concentrations. This relationship was independent of the cardiac history of the patient and
      suggests that the natriuretic peptide levels are to some degree modifiable by changing a
      patient's fluid distribution.

      In this study, we want to observe that if the level of BNP can predict the occurrence of
      acute kidney injury and the need of renal replacement therapy. Besides, we also want to see
      if BNP can be a useful and convenient marker to guide adjustment of optimal fluid status and
      then to improve outcome.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients > 18 y/o in ICU

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Acute coronary syndrome

          -  Congestive heart failure history

          -  Clinical pulmonary hypertension with various cause (iPAH, congenital heart disease,
             CTEPH, COPD with cor pulmonate,…)

          -  Patients with acute pulmonary embolism

          -  Chronic atrial fibrillation,

          -  Respiratory failure with high PEEP (>10 CmH2)

          -  Terminal cancer patients

          -  Patients with Bosmina therapy

          -  Patients received CPR (IHCA or OHCA)

study_pop.textblock: Critically ill patients in intensive care unit(older than 18 y/o)

clinical_study.keyword: BNP, acute kidney injury, fluid status
clinical_study.official_title: Exploring the Relationship Among Brain Natriuretic Peptide, Fluid Status and Acute Kidney Injury in Critically Ill Patients

primary_outcome.measure: Change from Baseline in serum creatinine level at 3 months

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
